intro: Bucephalophora aculeata f. plagiotropica, commonly known as the creeping sandwort, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Montiaceae. It is a low-growing perennial herb characterized by its prostrate or decumbent growth habit. The plant features small, white or pale pink flowers arranged in dense clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, linear, and often covered in fine hairs, adapting to arid or sandy environments. This subspecies is native to regions of southern Africa, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun.
